1.brief: properly, to hack, i.e. engrave (Judges 5:14, to be a scribe simply); by implication, to enact (laws being cut in stone or metal tablets in primitive times) or (gen.) prescribe
strictly nothingness; also trouble. vanity, wickedness; specifically an idol
to grave, by implication, to write (describe, inscribe, prescribe, subscribe)
toil, i.e. wearing effort; hence, worry, wheth. of body or mind
to grave, by implication, to write (describe, inscribe, prescribe, subscribe)

2.brief: to stretch or spread out; by implication, to bend away (including moral deflection); used in a great variety of application
judgement (the suit, justice, sentence or tribunal); by implication also strife
properly, dangling, i.e. (by implication) weak or thin
to pluck off; specifically to flay, strip or rob

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
a widow; also a desolate place
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)

3.brief: properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
remoteness, i.e. (concretely) a distant place; often (adverbially) from afar
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
who? (occasionally, by a peculiar idiom, of things); also (indefinitely) whoever; often used in oblique construction with prefix or suffix
to flit, i.e. vanish away (subside, escape; causatively, chase, impel, deliver)
where?; hence, whither?, when?; also hither and thither
to loosen, i.e. relinquish, permit, etc.
properly, weight, but only figuratively in a good sense, splendor or copiousness

4.brief: properly, a failure of, i.e. (used only as a negative particle, usually with a prepositional prefix) not, except, without, unless, besides, because not, until, etc.
to bend the knee; by implication, to sink, to prostrate
the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.
the bottom (as depressed); only adverbially, below (often with prepositional prefix underneath), in lieu of, etc.
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to turn back (hence, away) transitively or intransitively, literally or figuratively (not necessarily with the idea of return to the starting point); generally to retreat; often adverbial, again
properly, the nose or nostril; hence, the face, and occasionally a person; also (from the rapid breathing in passion) ire
properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
to stretch or spread out; by implication, to bend away (including moral deflection); used in a great variety of application

a scion, i.e. (literally) a stick (for punishing, writing, fighting, ruling, walking, etc.) or (figuratively) a clan
properly, the nose or nostril; hence, the face, and occasionally a person; also (from the rapid breathing in passion) ire

Laish, the name of two places in Palestine
Anathoth, the name of two Israelites, also of a place in Pal

31.brief: properly, to wave to and fro (rarely to flap up and down); figuratively, to rove, flee, or (causatively) to drive away
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
to be strong; causatively, to stregthen, i.e. (figuratively) to save (by flight)

32.brief: properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
to stand, in various relations (literal and figurative, intransitive and transitive)
to quiver (i.e. vibrate up and down, or rock to and fro); used in a great variety of applications (including sprinkling, beckoning, rubbing, bastinadoing, sawing, waving, etc.)
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
a house (in the greatest variation of applications, especially family, etc.)
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
Jerushalaim or Jerushalem, the capital city of Palestine

33.brief: Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a mass of persons (or figuratively, things), especially reg. organized forwar (an army); by implication, a campaign, literally or figuratively (specifically, hardship, worship)
properly, ornamentation, i.e. (plural) foliage (including the limbs) as bright green
to be high actively, to rise or raise (in various applications, literally or figuratively)
to fell a tree; generally, to destroy anything
to depress or sink (expectation figuratively, to humiliate, intransitive or transitive)

34.brief: to strike with more or less violence (beat, fell, corrode); by implication (of attack) to knock together, i.e. surround or circulate
a copse of bushes; hence, a forest; hence, honey in the comb (as hived in trees)
iron (as cutting); by extension, an iron implement
Lebanon, a mountain range in Palestine
to fall, in a great variety of applications (intransitive or causative, literal or figurative)
